So I guess it's obvious that you're unable to produce anything unique until you study your industry thoroughly enough. Here's your action plan: 1. Research your industry. Read a lot. Hi there I usually categorise what I write like this: If I'm writing on topics that I'm personally involved in like running, photography, fashion style, movies, etc. I get ideas for fresh content based on my personal experiences. Like if I'm blogging for a lifestyle publication and these days I'm wondering what to wear in such cold weather without looking like a slouch, I'll write that exactly - 7 tips to look hot in chilly weather, or something on those lines.If I'm writing on topics I stumble upon only at work like Investment Banking in India, decision Optimisation using business analytics, etc. I'll first shortlist the topics and run them on Google Keyword Planner in Google Adwords. For each topic, I will get 3–4 keywords, which I will then run on BuzzSumo to see what articles are hot and then I'll do my research. Then I'll create a content strategy with the data gathered so far, and with this method, I should have content ideas to last me around a month or so, even when I'm writing 3–4 days a week.This is my way. Hope it helps you :)

‘Fresh content’ is a relative term, and its definition varies from content to content. In order to start writing content in the first place, you need to define your need. There are different types of content, and each one of them has to be written differently. For example, if your content is for commercial purposes, the ‘freshness’ of your content should have a generic structure of information. If you’re creating content for engagement, the freshness of your content depends on your usage of latest keywords and referential metadata. If your content is for your personal blogs, then your content will be considered fresh if you write about things which people will understand and relate to the most. The main factor to be considered for writing fresh content is that you need to have ample research about the topic you’re writing about. Read a few blogs/ articles on that topic first, and try to explain your perspective in a fresh way.

As we all know that Google does not like outdated content in its SERPs so if you want to maintain your search engine rankings, you need to update your existing content on a daily basis. - Review the content for accuracy. - Add more text content. - Check for broken links. - Remove/ Update outdated graphics. - Update links that are pointing to old content or data that is no longer valid. - Review your meta descriptions. - Enhance your content with structured data. - Change the last updated date to reflect the data that the page was last updated. - Publish new content which are targetting new keywords.
